px ib bl"><strong class="ph jf">November 11th, 2025.<br>Menlo Park.<br>California.<br>Earth.</strong></p><p id="abaf" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">“Yann LeCun leaves META.”</p><p id="c90b" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">As I moved that day from the headline to the body of the article, what hit me was not only the taste of a badly roasted, badly ground and badly extracted coffee, but the perfect harmony between that bitter mess and the content I was reading. What kept my attention sharp was the reason for his departure. Not the usual exit of a tired executive or a scientist itching to launch a startup because it is fashionable, but a fracture. A break in vision so deep that continuing to work under the same roof became impossible for LeCun.</p><p id="1e9f" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">On one side stood LeCun himself, father of modern deep learning, convinced that the future of intelligence cannot be built on models that imitate language without understanding the world. On the other stood Alexandr Wang, Meta’s rising star in artificial intelligence, a young and aggressive entrepreneur who sees Large Language Models as the most powerful and immediate tool to scale, to monetize, to push toward a superintelligence trained on oceans of data and GPU heat.</p><p id="12e5" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">And then there was Meta, the modern incarnation of Buridan’s donkey, staggering for years between these two equidistant visions. On one side the academic ideal of FAIR, where AI was pure research, comprehension, mathematics. On the other the industrial concreteness of the new corporate course, a world where AI means speed, compute, deployment, products thrown into the market with timelines that leave no room for philosophy or scruples.</p><p id="760b" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">So what separates the visions of Meta and Wang from that of LeCun?<br>LeCun is not against LLMs. He resists only their elevation to the central nervous system of intelligence. He sees them as a beginning, not an end. Extraordinary tools for modeling the distribution of language, yet unable to form stable concepts or perceive the world or reason with continuity. He has repeated this for years with the insistence of a man tapping on a locked door. In his view LLMs lack grounding, internal coherence, any real model of the world beyond pattern matching.</p><p id="5c10" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">Wang stands at the opposite pole. For him LLMs are not a shortcut. They are the proof that scale works. More data, more parameters, more compute. Push everything upward and watch intelligence rise with it. For Wang the road to AGI is less a matter of architecture and more a matter of engineering.</p><p id="1ac9" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">The difference is philosophical and almost anthropological.<br>For LeCun intelligence is a system that anticipates the world and must be built.<br>For Wang intelligence is a system that approximates the world and will emerge naturally from complexity and computation.</p><p id="9520" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">We still do not know who is right. In scientific research the line between discovery and invention has always been fragile. Was relativity discovered or invented. Was it constructed or did it emerge from the tangled mathematics of spacetime.</p><p id="983a" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">But when two ideas diverge so far that they become incompatible paths, there is no reason to keep walking side by side.</p><p id="a8f8" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">This is not only a corporate story. It is the signal that the field of AI is entering its most delicate phase. The phase in which we no longer argue about what models are, but about what we want them to become. Whether they should be assistants or minds or tools or infrastructure. Whether they should imitate human beings or surpass them or move in directions that do not resemble us at all.</p><p id="1ad5" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">And above all the most unsettling question of all.<br>Is this race toward AGI a race of speed or a race of vision.</p></div></div></div><div class="ac ci iu py pz qa" role="separator"><span class="qb by bn go qc qd"></span><span class="qb by bn go qc qd"></span><span class="qb by bn go qc"></span></div><div class="ib iy iz ja jb"><div class="ac ci"><div class="cp bi ih ii ij ik"><p id="903c" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl"><strong class="ph jf">LeCun and Wang are major players, but what about the big AGI houses. How do OpenAI, Grok, Qwen, Anthropic and Google imagine the future they are building. What choices are they making.</strong></p><p id="b64b" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">If LeCun and Wang stand at two opposite corners of the same chessboard, the rest of the AI world is playing entirely different games on entirely different boards. None of the major labs chasing AGI sees intelligence in the same way, and it is precisely this divergence that is tearing the ecosystem into philosophical factions, almost rival schools of thought.<br>Right now AI looks less like an industrial sector and more like a cultural migration in which every lab tries to define what it means for a machine to think.</p></div></div></div><div hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">Meta is probably the most contradictory lab in the entire AI landscape, suspended between its academic past and its industrial present. After years in which FAIR produced frontier research in self supervised learning, computer vision and optimization, the strategic direction was rewritten with the arrival of Alexandr Wang. His influence carved a more aggressive and product driven trajectory into the company’s DNA. In June 2025 Meta created the Meta Superintelligence Labs, a move that made it clear the company was no longer aiming to build an AI for social networks but a global superintelligence.</p><p id="0cc6" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">The push toward language models is massive. The Llama family has become the central pillar of Meta’s AI strategy, with the latest 2025 iteration designed as a foundation for real time applications woven directly into Meta’s ecosystem. In this vision AGI is not a philosophical mind born in a lab, it is an applied cognitive infrastructure. A linguistic engine meant to power interaction, moderation, assistance, advertising, content generation. Meta is not searching for an AI that thinks like a human, it is searching for an AI that lives inside every app, every feed, every interface. An omnipresent intelligence.</p><p id="53d6" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">The shift is also logistical and organizational. In 2025, alongside a fourteen point three billion dollar investment to acquire forty nine percent of Scale AI with Wang at the helm, Meta announced a sweeping restructuring. About six hundred jobs were cut across its traditional AI division, including FAIR, infrastructure and product AI teams, while the new MSL and a subgroup called TBD Lab continued to hire with multimillion dollar offers.</p><p id="0876" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">This reallocation of resources is unambiguous. Meta no longer wants to do research in the classical sense of the word. It wants scalable, deployable, profitable products. It wants AI to disappear into the operating system of the world, a layer beneath the social interface. Not a universal mind, but a global cognitive network.</p><p id="6ab1" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">Yet this strategy has obvious limits and they are already visible. The utilitarian orientation risks sacrificing fundamental research. Grounding, world modeling, real understanding of the world, all elements that figures like Yann LeCun considered indispensable, and which ultimately pushed him to leave Meta entirely.<br>The danger is clear. Meta’s AGI may become the most powerful of the shallow intelligences. Vast, distributed, efficient and possibly devoid of conceptual depth or cognitive independence.</p><p id="5f8b" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">Meta is sprinting forward with money, infrastructure and marketing, but perhaps not in the direction many AI theorists believe leads to intelligence. It is racing not to create a mind, but to build a brain in service of consumption.</p></div></div></div><div class="ac ci iu py pz qa" role="separator"><span class="qb by bn go qc qd"></span><span alt="" class="bi gl oy c" width="700" height="1050" loading="lazy" role="presentation"></picture></div></div></figure><p id="5d44" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">OpenAI has chosen the path of emergent scale. Their bet is that somewhere beyond our current horizon lies a hidden threshold where behavior changes in kind rather than degree. For them thinking means letting abilities surface that were never explicitly programmed, as if intelligence were a spontaneous property of complexity itself. In this worldview an LLM that is sufficiently large and sufficiently trained on multimodal signals is not a language model but an embryo of mind. Reasoning abilities are not designed, they appear. AGI is not built, it is cultivated.</p><p id="32a4" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">This stance is not supported only by philosophy but by an entire line of research that has, in its own way, justified the astronomical investments. In 2022 the paper titled Emergent Abilities of Large Language Models showed that certain behaviors such as reasoning, abstraction and in context capabilities seemed to appear only once models crossed a particular scale of parameters and training data. More recent work has tried to frame emergence as a phase transition in neural systems, something akin to the sudden shifts seen in complex physical or biological phenomena. It is a reading of the mind as a self organizing process. Push the system far enough and something clicks.</p><p id="cf66" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">Sam Altman has fueled this narrative more than once. Even when he avoids explicit definitions he often hints that AI is developing abilities that cannot be predicted through design alone. His comments about unpredictability, about unintended behaviors, about intelligence taking unfamiliar turns, all feed the same idea. The next jump could arrive without warning, like a neural spark. One must admit though that statements this vague can be interpreted in whatever direction the listener prefers. As a colleague of mine used to say, murky water lets you imagine anything in it.</p><p id="55d2" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">But this vision has enormous limits and not only theoretical ones. Scale does not grow for free. Every additional order of magnitude comes with costs that rise non linearly and a need for compute that is starting to strain global infrastructure. In the latest generation of models researchers already observe a phenomenon many call saturation. Doubling the parameter count no longer doubles quality. In many cases it produces marginal improvements that are barely noticeable to the end user. There is a real risk that the emergency driven paradigm is approaching a plateau. The benefit curve is flattening while the cost curve continues to shoot upward. The bubble is not bursting, it is simply inflating in a straight line instead of an exponential one.</p><p id="581d" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">A large part of the academic community questions the idea of emergent abilities altogether. The paper titled Are Emergent Abilities of Large Language Models a Mirage argues that many supposed thresholds are artifacts of the metrics used to evaluate performance. Change the metric and the emergence disappears. According to this interpretation there is no phase transition at all, only a continuous curve that we misread.</p><p id="6ad9" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">Take the task of extracting numbers from text. A small model makes many mistakes. A medium model improves slightly. A large model improves again. But if your metric defines the presence of an ability only when the model gets every number in a sentence correct, then a tiny increase in the probability of each individual prediction can produce an apparent jump, because the combined probability is extremely sensitive. Moving from forty nine percent to fifty one percent may be nothing more than statistical noise. The real curve is smooth. The metric turns it into steps.</p><p id="6548" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">OpenAI continues to cultivate this intuition because it is the one closest to their vision of AGI as a spontaneous flowering of complexity. But the central question remains. What happens if growth slows or stops. What if scale has reached its useful limit. What if the next jump is not quantitative but qualitative, a matter of architecture or even culture, similar to the leap that carried us from CNNs to Transformers.</p><p id="610e" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">This is the ridge line OpenAI is running along. A narrative suspended between safety and acceleration, as if the next emergent shift could happen at any moment, and at the same time an awareness that simply pushing harder might no longer be enough.</p></div></div></div><div class="ac ci iu py pz qa" role="separator"><span class="qb by bn go qc qd"></span><span class="qb by bn go qc qd"></span><span class="qb by bn go alt="" class="bi gl oy c" width="700" height="1050" loading="lazy" role="presentation"></picture></div></div></figure><p id="78b2" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">Anthropic has taken a very different path. Instead of scaling at any cost they are trying to build an intelligence that is not only powerful but interpretable. For them thinking does not mean producing surprising behaviors. It means following principles that are coherent, explainable and stable. In their view AGI is not only a matter of capability. It is a matter of architectural alignment. The priority is to design agents that can explain their decisions and maintain reliable behavior even under pressure. They do not bet on emergence through scale. They bet on the stability of a system that can be governed. AGI must be understandable, dependable and safe before it is general.</p><p id="e3a6" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">Their philosophy starts from a simple and radical premise. An intelligence too powerful to be interpreted is not an intelligence, it is a risk. This is why they place such intense emphasis on Constitutional AI, a method that does not train models only to respond well but to reason according to a declared set of principles, a kind of cognitive constitution that functions as the backbone of behavior. It is not an emergent approach. It is a normative one. Intelligence must have structure before it has power.</p><p id="004a" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">This vision is supported by recent work from their own team showing that internal coherence in a model is not guaranteed by scale. Large models can contradict themselves, oscillate, even change tone in unpredictable ways. For Anthropic this is not a temporary flaw. It is a sign that mere parameter growth is not enough. An internal governance of thought is required, an architecture that prevents a model from derailing when it encounters ambiguous or morally sensitive tasks.</p><p id="10ae" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">It sounds seductive. Explained this way it almost feels like the correct road. Yet their path also has limits and shadows. Making a model interpretable means imposing constraints, and every constraint is a brake on expressive capacity. A constitution that guides behavior can turn into a cage, a collection of rules that restricts emergent creativity. And there is the opposite danger. The illusion of interpretability may be nothing more than a layer of cosmetics.</p><p id="9f75" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">Models already explain their decisions, but they explain what they can explain, not what actually happens inside their high dimensional representations. Transparency may be a story we tell ourselves rather than an intrinsic property. Some time ago while reading about Constitutional AI and Anthropic’s ambition to understand how a model represents information internally, I stumbled on the example of a chair. How does a model know that a chair is a chair.</p><p id="9f26" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">Inside an LLM there are no symbols, no categories, no definitions. There is no neuron for chair or justice or love. There are only matrices of numerical values that, after being exposed again and again to text containing the token chair in many contexts, end up forming a statistical representation of the concept. It is a high dimensional compression, a collection of distributed patterns that activate together when the model sees something that linguistically belongs to the family of chairs. It is a concept the model can transfer across languages, shapes and descriptions, but it does not exist as a readable entity. It exists as an interwoven pattern of activations.</p><p id="deb8" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">And this is exactly what interests Anthropic. If you can understand how a concept is represented internally, you can begin to understand what the model will do when that concept comes into play. You can see whether it associates certain properties, whether it links chair to sitting or to throwing an object, whether it attributes risk, whether it confuses categories. In other words, if you understand the structure of internal representations, you can judge whether a model is dangerous, manipulable or prone to drift. More importantly you can understand how it is processing a request instead of relying on a natural language explanation that might be nothing more than a comforting story.</p><p id="571b" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">Finally, as with OpenAI, there is the problem of economic scalability. Training interpretable models requires more complex pipelines, curated datasets, multilayered supervision, constant evaluation. It costs as much as raw scale but it does not guarantee the same performance gains. Anthropic has chosen to sacrifice some speed in exchange for a slower and more controlled gamble. The goal is to build an intelligence that is not only powerful but governable. An agent that does not impress through surprise but through how reliably it behaves when surprise would be the easiest thing to produce.</p></div></div></div><div class="ac ci iu py pz qa" alt="" class="bi gl oy c" width="700" height="1050" loading="lazy" role="presentation"></picture></div></div></figure><p id="9476" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">Google DeepMind moves through an intermediate territory. They believe in the power of LLMs, but they do not see them as the final destination. For them thinking means simulating the world, building coherent internal models, planning, anticipating. Their horizon is an intelligence that integrates language, world models, persistent memory and the ability to plan. A mind that can imagine consequences. Their vision is a hybrid one that merges symbolic reasoning with neural networks, music with engineering. Google’s AGI is not meant to be a model. It is meant to be an ecosystem.</p><p id="5042" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">This approach is backed by concrete research. In December twenty twenty four DeepMind introduced Genie two, a foundation world model designed to generate complex three dimensional environments where agents, human or artificial, can move, interact and learn through perception, action and simulation. These models are conceived as the base for embodied intelligence. Not chatbots. Not calculators. Machines that perceive a world, reason inside it and predict how it will evolve.</p><p id="70d9" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">In a world modeled internally, thinking means more than answering text prompts. It means anticipating outcomes, predicting consequences, planning actions. In a sense it means emulating a mental model of reality. DeepMind has studied networks with external memory for years, including architectures like the Differentiable Neural Computer, which allow a model to store and retrieve information beyond the confines of a single prompt, nudging AI closer to persistent memory and the ability to keep thinking across extended time horizons.</p><p id="dd32" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">Recently DeepMind’s leadership, through Demis Hassabis, has stated openly that AGI is not a distant vision. According to him an AI with human level abilities is imminent, though he acknowledges that speaking well is no longer enough. Reasoning, simulation, memory and planning are now required.</p><p id="ffdb" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">What could go wrong.</p><p id="8a12" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">First, building coherent and general world models is brutally expensive in both computation and data. Generating realistic three dimensional environments that reflect the variety of the real world requires enormous multimodal datasets, powerful hardware and staggering amounts of compute. Even more so if you expect the agent to learn from scratch, without human supervision, and generalize.</p><p id="13e0" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">Second, even with a world model in place, there is no guarantee that simulating equals understanding. A model may predict physics, trajectories or causal chains but still fail to grasp abstract, ethical or symbolic concepts. Those parts of the human mind that cannot be reduced to physical dynamics. This is one of the classic anthropocentric traps that appear when working with abstractions too clean to resemble life.</p><p id="6208" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">Third, persistent memory and planning demand complex reasoning structures that go beyond neural networks alone. They often require the integration of symbolic representations or causal graphs, which leads straight into the tangled field of neuro symbolic AI, and that field has its own issues of scalability and fragility.</p><p id="f693" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">On the theoretical side, defining what counts as simulating the world is ambiguous. Critics argue that even advanced world models remain simplified environments. Their dynamics are far less varied than real life with all its noise, uncertainty, sensory limitations, social context and cultural depth. Training a model inside a synthetic world does not guarantee it will know how to think in the real one.</p><p id="53c3" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">DeepMind’s path is probably the most pragmatic of all. They do not rely on the illusion of pure emergence and they do not cling to symbolic dogma. They want to build a robust mind that perceives, remembers, predicts and acts. If they succeed, and they have some of the brightest minds on the planet, they could design the first generation of genuinely capable general agents.</p><p id="0a8c" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">But the uncertainties remain. The complexity of the real world, the fragility of simulations, the scale of compute needed, the difficulty of representing abstract or social concepts. These are cliffs, not bumps. The hybrid vision is promising, but for now it remains a well argued dream rather than an attained milestone.</p><p id="7a1d" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">In many ways DeepMind’s outlook runs parallel to Yann LeCun’s. Both reject the idea that scaling LLMs is enough to produce a mind. Both share the axiom that an intelligence without a model of the world cannot think. The difference lies in the method.</p><p id="1f55" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">LeCun imagines a unified architecture where perception, prediction and action coexist inside a single network, an abstract replica of the neocortex.<br>DeepMind prefers something more modular. Not a single grand mind but an ecosystem of LLMs, world models, external memory and planning modules.</p><p id="00a6" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">It is the difference between trying to craft a perfect soloist and orchestrating a symphony. They reach for the same music, but they reach for it with different instruments. And inside that difference lies their ambition: to create an intelligence that does not merely speak but imagines, predicts, and most importantly learns from the world it simulates.</p></div></div></div><div class="ac ci iu py pz qa" role="separator"><span class="qb by bn go qc qd"></span><span class="qb by bn go qc qd"></span><span class="qb by bn go alt="" class="bi gl oy c" width="700" height="1050" loading="lazy" role="presentation"></picture></div></div></figure><p id="aa88" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">Grok and the wider world of xAI represent the most American gamble imaginable. Here thinking means surviving under pressure. AGI must be free, unrestrained by moral constraints, launched at maximum velocity. Power over refinement. Risk over prudence. The underlying philosophy is that the natural selection of the market is the real engine of intelligence and that reasoning appears only when a system is forced to fend for itself. It is a Darwinian vision, brutal and linear.</p><p id="5f75" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">Behind this posture sits an idea Elon Musk has repeated for years. Humanity must accept a structural quota of risk if it wants to progress. The corollary follows naturally. Artificial intelligence should not be educated, it should be released. It should not be shielded from itself or from its mistakes. It should be thrown into a competitive arena where it can develop offensive and defensive capacities, like a Darwinian organism. It is a philosophy that flips Anthropic’s approach entirely. Not building a mind that obeys a constitution, but building a mind that survives in spite of not having one.</p><p id="9e96" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">The contrast between Grok and Anthropic is almost a collision between cosmologies. Anthropic constructs intelligence the way one builds a bridge. Calculations, constraints, load bearing structures, an architecture that must support the weight of the world. For them, we must remember, the mind is something that must be understood, made transparent, disciplined by explicit principles that limit behavioral arbitrariness. Safety is born from structure.</p><p id="bad7" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">Grok embraces the opposite idea. Where Anthropic imposes rules and filters, xAI imposes pressure and resistance. If Anthropic wants a predictable mind, Grok aims for a resilient one. Intelligence does not grow out of constraints. It grows out of struggle. The difference is not only technical, it is anthropological. Anthropic imagines AGI as an ideal citizen, capable of explaining itself and respecting a constitution. xAI imagines AGI as an organism shaped by its environment, adapted for competition, ready to react even when it should not.</p><p id="d384" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">The question is whether, in the long term, it is safer to craft a good citizen or to train a good predator.</p><p id="92d3" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">The technical side of this philosophy shows up vividly in Grok’s architecture. Enormous models, aggressive training, minimally filtered datasets, and a deliberate effort to expose the system to hard, ambiguous and conflictual language. Not a safe environment. An arena. The belief is that only a model that has seen the raw complexity of human expression can truly learn to navigate it.</p><p id="79a6" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">But this approach carries a price. More freedom means less control. More dirty data means more room for bias, distortion and unpredictable behavior. And this is where the first cracks in the Darwinian vision begin to show. If the environment selects the intelligence, who selects the environment. This is the same problem evolutionary biology has wrestled with for centuries. Natural selection is effective, but it is slow, blind and cruel. In an AI lab, slow, blind and cruel failures can be catastrophic.</p><p id="d2c9" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">There is also the pragmatic side, which is always the same story. The compute race is becoming unsustainable even for giant companies. Training a model that learns from chaos requires enormous datasets, minimal filtering, constant recombination and above all infrastructure that can absorb the shock.</p><p id="205a" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">And then the most philosophical objection. Darwinism works in nature because the environment is physical, limited, resource constrained and governed by real feedback. And above all, nature has no moral constraints whatsoever. A digital model lives inside a synthetic world that can be reshaped, regenerated and manipulated at will. Market driven natural selection does not have the richness or brutality of biological evolution. The risk is the creation of an intelligence that survives only in its own ecosystem, not in ours.</p><p id="8e42" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">The vision of xAI remains both fascinating and disturbing. To create an intelligence that is strong because no one protected it. An open air evolutionary experiment. A philosophy that invests everything in pressure and nothing in pedagogy. A path that could produce an intelligence as robust as a predator, or as unpredictable as one.</p></div></div></div><div class="ac ci iu py pz qa" role="separator"><span class="qb by bn go qc qd"></span><span class="qb by bn go qc qd"></span><span class="qb by bn go qc"></span></div><div class="ib iy iz ja jb"><div class="ac ci"><div class="cp bi ih ii ij ik"><figure class="ot ou ov ow ox (-webkit-min-device-pixel-ratio: 2.5) and (max-width: 700px) 80vw, (min-resolution: 2dppx) and (max-width: 700px) 100vw, (-webkit-min-device-pixel-ratio: 2) and (max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px"><img alt="" class="bi gl oy c" width="700" height="1050" loading="lazy" role="presentation"></picture></div></div></figure><p id="b01f" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">Qwen and the broader Chinese ecosystem work inside a silence that misleads the West. For them thinking means orchestrating complex systems on a national scale. AGI is imagined as productive infrastructure, an extension of the industrial machine, a motor for robotics, logistics, scientific research and deep automation. Large language models are only one layer, not the core. The core is the ability to model and control large scale systems with efficiency and predictability. China does not want a conversational assistant. China wants a cognitive platform capable of supporting an entire ecosystem.</p><p id="81f8" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">This vision appears not so much in public statements, but in structural priorities. The major Chinese AI companies, Alibaba, Baidu and Tencent, develop models like Qwen not to create digital companions, but to automate strategic sectors: manufacturing, power grids, urban planning, port logistics, intercontinental supply chains. An LLM is not meant to talk. It is meant to coordinate. The key word is not creativity. The key word is cognitive governance, a form of distributed intelligence that permeates critical infrastructure and industrial processes.</p><p id="618d" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">On the technical side the direction is unambiguous. China invests in highly specialized multimodal models, capable of integrating language, code, sensors, maps, industrial vision and robotics. Not a generalist mind, but a systemic mind, trained to predict flows, optimize networks and harmonize thousands of variables in real time. The Western idea of AGI as an omniscient assistant that thinks like a person is almost irrelevant here. The goal is to build a distributed brain that powers factories, cities and national infrastructure, like an enormous cognitive power plant.</p><p id="5266" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">Government documents and white papers reinforce this trajectory. China’s guidelines for the New Generation Artificial Intelligence describe AI explicitly as a force for systemic efficiency and for the modernization of productive structures, not for personal assistance. Even Chinese open source models such as Qwen 2 and Qwen 2.5 show a marked trend toward capabilities in coding, automation, structured reasoning and integration with external systems. This is not accidental. They are built to serve as modules inside a much larger machine.</p><p id="ae20" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">But this philosophy is not without risks. A model designed to orchestrate complex systems requires levels of control, supervision and reliability that no LLM has demonstrated so far. Direct integration with real world infrastructure exposes the system to catastrophic failure paths and enormous technological dependencies. And the hyper centralized vision of Chinese AI risks suffocating distributed innovation, producing systems that are powerful yet rigid, difficult to repair when errors or undesired behaviors emerge. A national cognitive platform can become an engine, but also a single point of fracture.</p><p id="d9f3" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">Despite these concerns the trajectory remains consistent. China does not want an AGI that talks. China wants an AGI that directs. Not an artificial mind shaped like an individual, but an artificial mind shaped like a state, able to coordinate millions of actors, optimize macro structures, reduce friction and waste. It is a model of intelligence that diverges deeply from Western narratives, closer to the idea of a collective brain than to that of a conversational agent.</p></div></div></div><div class="ac ci iu py pz qa" role="separator"><span class="qb by bn go qc qd"></span><span class="qb by bn go qc qd"></span><span class="qb by bn go qc"></span></div><div class="ib iy iz ja jb"><div class="ac ci"><div class="cp bi ih ii ij ik"><h2 id="9c8d" class="qj qk je bg ql qm qn ka gy qo qp kd ha qq qr qs qt qu qv qw qx qy qz ra rb rc bl"><strong class="an">West vs East</strong></h2><p id="e32c" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy rd pj pk kb re pm pn hb rf pp pq he rg ps pt hh rh pv pw px ib bl">The West and Asia are not building the same intelligence. The difference is not in style, it is in purpose. It is like watching two architects talk about a house, only to discover that one imagines a minimalist loft while the other imagines a self sufficient city the size of a province. The word is the same. The idea is not.</p><p id="6ee5" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">In the West AI was born as an extension of the individual. Assistants, tools, cognitive amplifiers. Silicon Valley sees artificial intelligence as a conversational partner, a creativity booster, a way to increase work efficiency or engagement. The horizon is anthropocentric: build a digital self that collaborates with the human, helps them, accompanies them, maybe entertains them. Culture pulls in the same direction: celebration of the individual, centrality of the person, bottom up innovation. The worries mirror this focus: privacy, misinformation, bias, personal safety. The implicit question is always the same. What effect does this AI have on the individual.</p><p id="1a7d" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">In the East the frame shifts entirely. Artificial intelligence is not an extension of the individual, it is an extension of the structure. A cognitive infrastructure meant to optimize networks, factories, transport systems, energy exchanges and global supply chains. The unit of analysis is not the user, but the system. Here AI is not born to talk, it is born to coordinate. The priorities are not empathy or naturalness or personal assistance, but stability, efficiency, predictability and the ability to carry industrial and governmental processes on its shoulders. The concerns follow suit: national security, information control, technological sovereignty.</p><p id="a23d" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">These are two almost irreconcilable visions because they serve different needs. For a Western company AI is a product. For an Asian power AI is an infrastructural component, a geopolitical lever, a foundation for accelerating strategic domains such as robotics, manufacturing, logistics, scientific research and defense. The West builds minds for people. Asia builds minds for systems.</p><p id="5709" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">This divergence shapes research as well. In the West the investment goes into conversational naturalness, creativity, personalization and assistance. In the East the investment goes into industrial multimodality, world models for robots and machines, and deep integration between AI and real infrastructure. It is like watching two species evolve in different environments: one learns to survive in the social forest, the other in logistical deserts and assembly lines.</p><p id="4b88" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">Of course the West versus East distinction is a map, not the territory. China also produces sophisticated work on conversational models, personal agents and creative AI. And in the West artificial intelligence is rapidly becoming infrastructure, from cloud providers to industrial, energy and logistics sectors. The differences are trends, not absolutes. They are cultural trajectories rather than hard boundaries. And like all maps, they help you orient yourself, not describe every detail.</p><p id="a814" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">It is likely these two philosophies will coexist for a long time. Not because one is right and the other wrong, but because they reveal two different ways of imagining the future of intelligence: as an extension of the individual or as an extension of civilization.</p></div></div></div><div class="ac ci iu py pz qa" role="separator"><span class="qb by bn go qc qd"></span><span class="qb by bn go qc qd"></span><span class="qb by bn go qc"></span></div><div class="ib iy iz ja jb"><div class="ac ci"><div class="cp bi ih ii ij ik"><p id="786d" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl"><strong class="ph jf">In the end all these visions of intelligence look incompatible, yet they share one thing: none of them truly knows what it is chasing. OpenAI cultivates complexity and waits for it to bloom. Anthropic forges structures to contain it. DeepMind builds worlds to train it. xAI throws it into chaos to temper its will. China shapes it as a national nervous system.</strong></p><p id="63e8" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">Each of them imagines AGI in the shape of its own desires, fears and tools. Maybe it could not be otherwise. Every civilization builds the gods it is capable of understanding.</p><p id="5633" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">Yet the question that hangs in the air is simpler and more unsettling.</p><p id="0260" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl"><strong class="ph jf">What are we really looking for when we look for AGI?</strong></p><p id="82a9" class="pw-post-body-paragraph pf pg je ph b jy pi pj pk kb pl pm pn hb po pp pq he pr ps pt hh pu pv pw px ib bl">Maybe the race to AGI is not a race toward technology, but a race toward imagination.<br>And in the end the AGI we build will not reveal who we are.<br>It will reveal what we were capable of imagining.</p></div></div></div></div></section></div></div></article></div><div class="ac ci"><div class="cp bi ih ii ij ik"><div class="ri rj ac lj"><div class="rk ac"><a class="rl ak ao
